qas.question: what is evaporation and sublimation in a vacuum?
When does outgassing become important in all solid or liquid materials?

answers.text: vacuum pressure falls below this vapour pressure

qas.question: Why can outgassing products ruin a space mission?
What does liquid have the same effect as in a telescope?
What can solar cells limit the achievement of?
On what kind of surfaces can space missions happen?
What is the cost of a telescope for a space mission?
What is a solid touching a cold surface called?

context: Evaporation and sublimation into a vacuum is called <a0_0><b7_0>outgassing<b7_0/><a0_0/>. All materials, solid or liquid, have a small vapour pressure, and their outgassing becomes important when the <a1_0>vacuum pressure falls below this vapour pressure<a1_0/>. In man-made systems, outgassing has the same effect as <b3_0>a leak<b3_0/> and can limit the achievable <b4_0>vacuum<b4_0/>. Outgassing products may condense on <b5_0>nearby colder surfaces<b5_0/>, which can be troublesome if they <a2_0>obscure optical instruments<a2_0/> or react with other materials. This is of great concern to space missions, where an obscured telescope or solar cell can ruin an <b6_0>expensive<b6_0/> mission.
